title: FORMING IMPRESSIONS OF PERSONALITY
description: This classic study investigates the processes by which unified impressions of personality are formed. The author challenges the view that impressions are formed by the simple summation of independent traits. Through a series of experiments, Asch demonstrates that certain 'central' traits (such as 'warm' and 'cold') have a disproportionate effect on the final impression, while other 'peripheral' traits have less impact. The research also explores how the meaning of a trait changes depending on its context and the order in which information is received (the primacy effect). The findings suggest that impressions are structured wholes rather than mere collections of discrete characteristics....

findings.main_hypothesis: The characteristic 'warm-cold' produces striking and consistent differences of impression.
The total group results are a statistical artifact; individual subjects quickly revealed strong and consistent differences, tending to be either consistently positive or negative.
The changes introduced by the transition from 'polite' to 'blunt' were far weaker than those found in Experiment I.
Immediately 'warm' drops as a significant characteristic in relation to the others.
The quality 'calm' was not the same under the two experimental conditions.
The impression produced by A is predominantly that of an able person with shortcomings; B impresses as a 'problem' whose abilities are hampered.
There is still a definite tendency for A to produce a more favorable impression with greater frequency.
The majority of Group 1 experienced difficulty in forming an impression on the basis of the six terms, seeing the person as a mass of contradictions.
There develops a one-directed impression, far stronger than any observed in the preceding experiments.
A remarkably wide range of qualities is embraced in the dimension 'warm-cold'. It even includes physical characteristics.
Qualities which, abstractly taken, are identical, are infrequently equated, while qualities which are abstractly opposed are equated with greater frequency.
